title: Fantasy book series: Would it be better to establish the world and magic system in the first book and explore the minor details as the story needs them or to establish a little bit of the magic system and world throughout all the books? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think it really comes down to personal preference. And my preference is that I hate infodumps. I’ve read only one author who actually got me interested in infodumps, and that’s H. Beam Piper explaining how the Ullerites work in Uller Uprising. Apart from that, my preference, both when I read and write, is to integrate details as they become relevant in the story. And once in a while, go into a expositional tangent no longer than a paragraph if it helps establish the feel of the world, even if it doesn’t directly drive the plot. However, that’s what I put on the page. But I generally establish the rules of magic, super-science, or whatever, before I start writing. I do this to maintain internal consistency. And before I introduce a new idea I thought of six chapters in, I can consult my notes and see if I’m contradicting myself now. If not, it’s good. If so, I need to decide if it’s worth doing the necessary rewrites of earlier chapters. The thing is, as the author, you will know more than ever makes it onto the page. But many authors give into the temptation to show off all that worldbuilding with long boring info-dumps. But we as readers don’t need to know that. We don’t need to see your world vivisected before our eyes. If it works, makes sense, and is internally consistent, then we will be able to tell that there are bones and sinews beneath the skin of your story. For example, you don’t need the entire background on how the intersection of the internet and magic gave rise to net-spirits, you just need to know that Selena the tech-witch uses them. Several stories later, you need to know that they don’t really understand the outside world, so while they’ll gleefully do as Selena asks, they sometimes return unusual results. Like when she asked them to retrieve a video file in a computer that was air-gapped, and she didn’t know the exact file name, they returned every single scrap of video file on that computer including all the porn.  Original question-Fantasy book series: Would it be better to establish the world and magic system in the first book and explore the minor details as the story needs them or to establish a little bit of the magic system and world throughout all the books?

Fantasy book series: Would it be better to establish the world and magic system in the first book and explore the minor details as the story needs them or to establish a little bit of the magic system and world throughout all the books? There isn’t a single answer to this question. Some works of fiction attempt to explain the world—and hence the magic that is part of it—in exposition or de facto exposition, whereas others take the approach of revealing it in dialogue and plot points. Sometimes, stories demand to be told in certain ways. Whichever approach makes the most sense for the story being told is the best approach. If it doesn’t serve the story being told, it probably doesn’t belong in the story.

Build the word as you go. Don’t fall into the elaborate trap of spending countless hours building this wonderful world and at the end of the day have no story to put in it. Trickle the information to the reader as you go rather than bomb them with a huge info dump in the first novel. If you need x type of magic then you need to find x type of magic user that can join or teach. Etc

Remember the first rule of fantasy: humans in an alien world or aliens in our world, not both. If your characters are to accomplish anything in the first book, they will be forced to explore the world and the magic system, using what they can to survive and work toward their goals. Save the minor details for book 2

If the magic is a central theme, you need to set up the basics. For instance, what is the cost? What are the limitations? Is this a normal part of the culture. Then you can slowly build on that. I would look at the Glassmaker’s Apprentice or Green Rider series or the Mask of Shadows. They all layout basic magic and build on it.

You should watch Brandon Sanderson’s lectures to his BYU writing class before you do anything else. Your question shows that you don’t really understand what you’re getting into (or trying to get into). In general, world building is easy, and writing a story is very difficult.

No one gives a crap about your magic system. They need to care about your characters, and you move on from there. Maybe your character has to learn the magic system to save his dog. Something like that.

response.answer_text: The first option can become an info-dump, it’s far better to explore both the world and the magic system through the books, but the author has to have an idea of both as they’re writing.
